speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 06-1322, Federal Express Corporation v. Holowecki. Ms. Lensing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, EEOC Form 5 is labelled "Charge." And would it be your position that if an employee filled out that form and submitted it to the EEOC, but the EEOC made a mistake and did not notify the employer, that that would not be a charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, why don't we do exactly that here? I mean, you say that the proper thing to do, now a charge labelled Form 5 has been filed, is to dismiss this lawsuit; and then we wait 60 days; and the identical lawsuit is reinstated. Why shouldn't the court simply toll the case and say, now we have a proper Form 5. The employer didn't get a chance to engage in settlement. So we hold on to the case and allow the 60 days to elapse, and then the complaint is there. Why isn't that the appropriate solution for this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you said the same complaint could be filed at the end of the conciliation. What difference does it make that you have a piece of paper there? What I don't understand is the only effect of your position -- dismiss the whole thing, 60 days, start over -- is you're making the plaintiff file an additional filing fee. The complaint has already been filed. The filing fee has been paid. Now, everything would work out just the same except the plaintiff has to pay a second filing fee. In the court there are certain inefficiencies if it's first dismissed and then they have to docket it again. So I don't see any -- it doesn't seem to make any sense to me.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I think -- I think you're right about that. I mean, once the lawyer's involved and they're in litigation and all that, they're not going to take conciliation efforts with the same light as before. But the question is whether the remedy for that, which is some unfairness to you, is to throw the suit out or try to fix it as much as possible, such as through a stay or dismissing without prejudice or something. Why should the Plaintiff -- it's not his fault that the EEOC didn't notify you. Why should he suffer the categorical sanction of dismissal simply because it's a little unfairness to you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why -- why should the - - the filing fee penalty, in effect, go to the plaintiff when it wasn't the plaintiff's fault?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: May I interrupt you to this extent: As I understand it, if -- your position, if the plaintiff had filed on Form 5 and the EEOC had done nothing and the plaintiff then brought suit, you'd be making the same argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand that. I mean, that -- that seems to me a very strange argument. You say since -- since the EEOC must give notice when a charge is filed, if it doesn't give notice, no charge has been filed. That doesn't make sense. I mean, it's just like saying, you know, you have a civil rule, a rule of civil procedure, that says, you know, after a complaint has been filed there shall be an answer within 60 days. And if no answer is filed, no complaint has been filed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, it just doesn't track.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So give me another one that will enable me to rule in your favor?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right. Now, does - - does the person who's filed a proper charge know whether notice has been given or not? Is a copy of the notice always given to the filer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: After she had a lawyer. But is it -- is it not the practice at the EEOC when you're dealing with an unrepresented person who files the intake questionnaire and if the SEC reviewer thinks that it fits within the statute, that the Form 5 will be filled out, not by the layperson, but by the EEOC officer herself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that's not the question. The question I asked is if they decide that the, what the intake -- the information on the intake questionnaire fits within the statute so that the claim can go forward, isn't it the practice not to ask the layperson to fill out the Form 5, but for the EEOC to do it itself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, it has to be signed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, she filled out hers after she was already in court and had a lawyer. But I thought that this statute, as all the statutes EEOC administers, are designed for claims that are put forth initially largely by unrepresented people. And the notion is that the agency should make it as easy as possible for them to get through the legal process.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It said it wasn't a charge, didn't it? Didn't it say that it's not a charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Precharge counseling.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do we know - - perhaps this is a question your friend on the other side will be able to answer better than you. But do we know where she got the form, why she filled it out? I couldn't find in the record whether this was given to her by someone at the EEOC or whether she downloaded it from the website or what.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I agree completely with everything you said. I just don't understand your leap from government incompetence to saying the plaintiff loses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What happens -- what happens if -- in this case it's not a problem, but I can imagine it would be in many cases -- - if you have a 300-day or a 180-day problem, you withdraw the complaint, and then you're out there and the clock keeps ticking, and you get past the 300 days and you are totally out. That's why it's important not to follow - - to say, well, it's, it doesn't make any difference, if we dismiss this complaint, she comes back in 60 days. Well, but 60 days may be 360 days.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you think Ms. Kennedy is entitled to equitable tolling in this case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I guess she, reasonably or otherwise, thought there already was a lawsuit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Wasn't she appealing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Wasn't she appealing the dismissal?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Did you undertake conciliation efforts after her formal, her filing of the Form 5 charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If the employee files an intake questionnaire but not a Form 5, would you say that there would be equitable tolling, or would you say that the employee wouldn't be entitled to equitable tolling because the employee didn't file the right form?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I don't see much difference between the substance of these two forms, other than the fact that the Form 5, I think, requires a listing of the number of employees that the employer has. What -- they basically cover the same ground.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, I don't understand that, because EEOC is a responsible agency. Congress has told it: You weed out the people complaining about something that happened in Paris, and then you give notice. But the notice obligation -- and I understand it is EEOC's, not the complainant's. So we would not expect this agency -- yes, it messed up in this case - - routinely not to give notice, routinely not to engage the employer in conciliation efforts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the new form, the EEOC's new form -- I suppose responsive to this case and others like it -- that says if you don't file any other administrative complaint, we'll count the intake questionnaire as the charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If the EEOC treats it as a charge, then the EEOC is obliged to give notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where -- where does it say if you don't file it's only - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's the new form.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And where in the form that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The new form does say that, that if no other paper is filed, this can be treated as a charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Doesn't that eliminate the whole purpose of the -- of the preliminary document, to weed out those charges that relate to employment in France?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It will -- it will be a charge even if it's in France?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think that's right. I think what it boils down to is it'll be a charge if we decide to give notice, and it won't be a charge if we don't decide to give notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which is very nice for the EEOC, but not - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, the Government relied in its brief very heavily on the Chevron case, saying we should defer to the agency's regulations, and on the Auer case, saying we defer to the agency to tell us what its regulations mean. And you didn't cite either of those cases in your reply brief. So I wonder what your answer is to that argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But if they do that why can't -- and you don't -- if they don't give you the notice, well, then you can complain, they didn't give us the notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But if you're not hurt by it, what difference does it make?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if you don't get it, you can't complain, if you actually knew about it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you didn't know about it, then -- then you have a complaint.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well -- well, then you'd have the complaint if you didn't, et cetera, but so what? In other words, if the EEOC wants to have a very broad definition that turns 90 percent of its - - whatever this thing is called, the statement -- I forgotten the name, sorry. What's the name of this document? The intake questionnaire.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Intake questionnaire.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. If it has a broad definition that says this counts as a charge, so what? Let it do it. Who's hurt?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if they don't, you complain about that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You complain just as you're doing now, in court. You just the same words, but instead of using the words as against the word "charge," you use those same words you've all said in your excellent arguments, except you attack the fact you didn't get the notice, and there you're really hurt. Or if you're not, it doesn't matter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, all right. So what's wrong with that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And you're only - - when you say you're hurt, the only prejudice that you rely on is the fact that you didn't have an opportunity to go through prelitigation conciliation.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But -- but my point is, you're not alleging prejudice from the lack of prompt notice. In other words, it's not a situation where you'd say if we had notice we would have done this, and that would have prevented everything.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Your only prejudice is the lack of conciliation period.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know whether that's true in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know whether -- I mean the difference -- what you are suggesting would be perfectly fine is once the charge was filed, and this is a lawsuit, and then you would investigate or whatever, but you would be under exactly the same disadvantage if the time lapse has meant that employees have left, that you have -- you have removed evidence as old and disposable. It wouldn't -- you would -- on your scenario of what would be the right way to do this lawsuit, you would be -- you would suffer the same disabilities in terms of documents and witnesses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. I thought you said you were deprived of something else. I mean, the statute provides for a conciliation process in which you can talk to the employee and say, you know, what happened? And you may well be able to satisfy the employee with -- before -- before she lawyers up. I think it's a big disadvantage to -- to have no contact with the employee until there's a lawyer on the other side, and you can't talk to her confidentially; you can't make a conciliation notice. I think that's a considerable disadvantage, and it's - - it's a situation that the statute did not envision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, as a practical matter, you can't conciliate after suit anyway. You can negotiate with the lawyer - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- on the other side.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: How is it -- how is it new? I thought that you argued for that test in the court of appeals.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, didn't -- didn't your brief say that was the appropriate test?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, you -- I know you're bound by precedent, but if you think it's wrong, you can say it's wrong. And, as I understand, you did not say it was wrong; you adopted it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what is your test? When is it a charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And don't tell me when notice is given.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: My goodness. It's like saying there's no complaint until an answer is filed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's just not true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, only because I'm sane. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If she had the obligation to give notice, you would have a much stronger argument, but the statute places that burden on the EEOC, not on the lay complainant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But there can't be equitable tolling unless she has really filed a charge. So sooner or later -- you cannot run away from it - - you're going to have to give us a definition of what a charge is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're only going to give her equitable tolling if in fact she's, she's filed a charge. And you don't give me any -- unless you want to fall back on the manifest destiny rule or - - (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Lensing. Mr. Rose.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is this after the real charge was filed or what everybody concedes - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The charge form.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But suit was pending at that time. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's pretty risky.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Answer my question. Was suit already filed at that point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Wait. I'm sorry. during that whole period?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's the only number of mistakes they have made; is that what you're saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm astounded if that's the only number of mistakes they made, from 19 - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, with respect to FedEx.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But are you telling us stuff that's not in the record at all? Why is that relevant to the argument here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What is the point of these statistics? To show that conciliation wouldn't have done any good? Is that what you - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I thought conciliation was an important policy of the EEOC.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you want us to write an opinion saying, we're not concerned with conciliation? We just - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if the person fills out an intake form, checks the box that says "I do not consent to have my employer notified"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What's -- what's wrong with this? Why don't I -- I mean, I do believe that the thing either is a charge or isn't a charge before the EEOC decides whether it's going to give notice or not. It either is or isn't. Now, what about this: It is a charge if it reasonably appears to be a charge, or if you want to say "manifest intent," that's okay, too. Now, if you signed a document which -- which says that it is a prefiling document and the purpose is to discuss a future charge, it seems to me you know, or ought to know, that this is not a charge. And we can't run the system for people who are either illiterate or don't even have friends who are literate. We can't run a system that way. So I look at this, and I say this is not a charge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now, if the EEOC chooses to give notice, then I guess you could say one that's close to the boundary line becomes a charge retroactively, and there is -- there is no harm done. You can have the counseling, and so forth. But when you come in with something that doesn't look like a charge, it seems to me if there is no notice given and you get into the situation that is here where the company has been deprived of the conciliation opportunity, deprived of the opportunity to preserve evidence and whatnot, it seems to me the fault should lie on your client, because she filed something that any reasonable person should know is not a charge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Whatever it was, this thing says it's a precharge document.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: This is where -- you're reading from where?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is that in the record?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Rose, I'm having trouble figuring out -- she not only filed this intake questionnaire; she also filed a lengthy affidavit.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Where did all this stuff come from?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Did these friends file charges on intake questionnaires?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: On Form 5.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you know why she signed the intake questionnaire on two different dates?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You were representing her at that point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why do you think -- why do you think they must have lost it? Why did you think they must have lost it: Because she hadn't been given a number?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even if they treat it as a charge, they don't docket it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I really think the problem here is the EEOC, rather than anybody else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It does, indeed, have this form which says -- which says that its purpose - - information provided on this form will be used by Commission employees to determine the existence of the facts relevant to a decision as to whether the Commission has jurisdiction and to provide such precharge filing counseling, blah, blah, blah. All of that, however, is contained as part of the Privacy Act statement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And if the filer is not interested in keeping any of it confidential, I wouldn't even read the Privacy Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what kind of an agency is this? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose they made a mistake here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What I think Miss Lensing, one of her more basic points is this: There is a statute. And the statute says the EEOC shall send prompt notice in part to the conciliation. And she adds, if we get the notice, we also start getting evidence and preserving it and talking to people. There are a lot of things they would like to do with that notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, I replied to that, well, okay, they complain about the lack of notice. But her response is, sure, they sometimes don't give notice when they file a charge. That's just a mistake. But if you start calling these documents charges, well, they never give notice, so they will never do it. It will be a big problem, so, therefore, don't call them charges. Now, I want to know what your answer is to the first part of what I said. My -- I was assuming that if the employer is really hurt, there is a statute and a rule and the statute and the rules say you have to give notice and if they are hurt by that, they can complain about it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But they must make mistakes in their history when they file charges and didn't give notice. So what does the law tell us? If you found it any case ever where the EEOC didn't give the notice, now the complainant files a lawsuit and it's not the complainant's fault, her response is work out some kind of equitable tolling. But there must be law on this, because this couldn't -- this is a big agency and they must have sometimes in the past forgotten to give notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What does the law say happens when they don't give notice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, it wouldn't be a defense. I mean, it's not this complainant's fault. It's the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You'd have to work out some kind of equitable tolling or something. I think she's right about that. There is no law to your knowledge or what is there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where does that appear? Where does that appear?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In its very definition of a "charge," it says a charge shall be in writing and shall name the prospective respondent and shall generally - - shall generally allege the discriminatory acts. That's what it must contain.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It doesn't say that anything that contains that is a charge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I could write out something that contains all three of those things. Would that be a charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right. Let's try something else.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I like my cite better. If you look at 1626.3 on page 351, it says: 'Charge' shall mean a statement filed with the Commission by, or on behalf of, an aggrieved person which alleges that the main prospective defendant has engaged in, or is about to engage in, actions in violation" - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But if an employee files something like that and says I don't consent to notification of the employer, can that be a charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, then, all intake questionnaires are a charge, because they all contain that. I mean that definition is simply inconsistent with the -- with the agency's assertion that it has something called an intake questionnaire which does not constitute a charge unless -- I don't know -- unless there's manifest whatever it is. That's inconsistent because all of those intake questionnaires contain all of that information - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- set forth in 26.3.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, there may be none, but if the -- if the employee indicates by the box checked that the employee does not want the company to know that the employee is making whatever this is, this statement - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- how can it be regarded as a charge against the employer which sets in effect a litigation process?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But you're okay because on that criterion your -- your client said, yes, you can tell them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Rose. Mr. Heytens.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Heytens, let me tell you going in that my -- my main concern in this case, however the decision comes out, is to do something that will require the EEOC to get its act in order, because this is nonsense: These regulations that are contradicted by forms; this failure to give notice, but it's okay because it's a charge anyway. This whole situation can be traceable back to the agency, and I -- whoever ends up bearing the burden of it, it's the agency's fault, and this scheme has to be revised.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's within 10 days of the charge, but that assumes, it seems to me, what's to be proven. I mean what is the charge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If -- if the prefiling, the intake thing, is not a charge, there is no problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can you not make that not a charge by saying in bold letters on the top: This is not a charge. If you want a charge, ask for Form 5?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why do the courts have to struggle with this when the agency could put in bold letters at the top: This is a charge or this is not a charge? Why do Federal district judges have to inquire into manifest intent from now until doomsday?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the practical problem: I want to know where do I read what the definition of a "charge" is in the EEOC rules. The three criteria that it has certain information in it can't be the rule. It can't be the rule because we already know that it isn't a charge if the person says I don't want it to become public. So, where do I read the rule that you just said? That it -- an intake questionnaire that satisfies these three conditions becomes a charge if it reflects the manifest intent of the person who files it that it be a charge. You said that. That's a pretty modestly clear rule, except it isn't totally. And they qualify -- where do I read that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: We use the word there "manifest intent"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Ah. Well, I read those regs, and those regs had a definition that can't possibly be right as applied to "intake questionnaire," because they make it a charge when the person says I don't want notice. So we know that isn't the thing. I also know what you just said does sound like a rule. I just want to know where to read it, because I don't think you'd refer to a rule of an agency, though normally we do -- but you don't refer to a rule that doesn't exist; you don't refer to a rule that nowhere can be found; you don't refer to a rule that is internally inconsistent. So, before I defer, I would just like to know where the clear rule that you stated can be found.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, I just want to read it somewhere.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So that if I were not here having you in front of me, as many people don't have you in front of them, where I would go to read just what you said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is a complaint different from an intake questionnaire?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why should we defer to an agency regulation when people in the agency hardly ever follow it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you didn't - - in this case you didn't treat it as a charge, because you didn't give notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But you said there were going to be four places. I want to write them down.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: One is 48 Fed. Reg. 148?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, the other three.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where is that in CFR?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do we give Chevron deference to things like your internal compliance manual and these other memos?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Under the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Heytens, is it true that the Form 5 for somebody who's not represented by counsel is usually done by EEOC itself? Is it that true?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Heytens, what's your solution for the situation where the EEOC treats it as a charge, but doesn't give notice, which is what has happened here? How do you think that should play out?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that's on the notice point. Going back to the other, more important point, your words that I found quite useful are the "manifest intent," that shows a manifest -- are those words going to be in these four sources that I look up?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No. I suspect not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Therefore -- I'm - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Just to get one thing perfectly clear in my mind, does that mean if the intake questionnaire is checked not consent, that would not be a charge?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Heytens. Miss Lensing, you have a minute left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How do we fix it? You haven't gotten notice, you haven't had a chance to conciliate -- how do we fix it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Miss Lensing. The case is submitted.
